text: so thanks for having me I'm your
friendly federal bureaucrat local like
the accent here to tell you about our
Medicaid program your Medicaid program
and what we've done with AWS but before
I get to that in order for you to really
understand this story I want to make
sure everybody has a little bit of
information about Medicaid this probably
won't make you popular at your next
dinner party when you share these fun
facts but it will make me feel better
that you know what I'm talking about
medicaid covers 74 million American and
health insurance 74 million
that's more than Medicare the fun fact
it covers more than half of all births
in the United States and more than half
of long-term care for elderly and
disabled so it's clearly a huge payer
and it's mostly children actually when
you add up all of the numbers we cover a
lot of children so Medicaid is federally
funded for the most part there's some
state match but it's really state
administered so it's like fifty-one
little Medicare really because those
states have a lot of flexibility but
that doesn't mean that at a national
level we don't want to be able to answer
questions like so how many of those
pregnant women actually got the normal
routine of prenatal care or where are
people going to access behavioral health
services how many people are getting
opioid treatment those are good
questions kind of hard to answer when
you're looking at 51 separate program so
about four or five years ago we decided
to up our game on the kind of data that
we collect from and with States to be
able to understand these trends across
the Medicaid program nationally because
if I should have mentioned also about
500 billion dollars a year so good to
know
little little metrics in there right so
we increased our data increase the
number of variables help States bring
them in and we were thinking all along
like this is great music
we can answer and this is what we're
going to do and as we started to do the
federal bill that federal catcher's mitt
we started to think about the size and
scale of the data
I mean seriously just California alone
would probably jam up our data centers
right and we knew that this wasn't data
just for data collection sake this was
data to use we wanted to be able to
answer those questions and to have a
data-driven culture and you don't get a
data-driven culture if the blue circle
of death comes up and you wait and you
wait and you wait and you wait for that
query right you've lost your people
because most of the people I'm trying to
bring into this culture are not data
walks and data scientists most of them
are policy people so performance was
really important and not competing
against everything else that CMS does
and has annexed bandwidth and size and
scalability was really important because
the data is cumulative we weren't
building just for now we're building
from four years from now so just to give
you a sense we have about 72 terabytes
of data and we're bringing in five more
years of California right now historic
data so just California alone is 900
million records a month I just want you
to think about how fast we're going to
get to a crazy amount of scale and that
we can't have any compromise and that
ability to answer the questions right
that's the point who's getting prenatal
care how many kids are getting
vaccinated where do we have access
issues what's the treatment pattern what
are our highest cost drug important
question so we had at this stage a
Silicon Valley startup firm working with
us see it can happen government and
Silicon Valley startups it can happen
and they said natively like in their
initial proposal we can build this for
you this is kind of easy this is a
mosquito bite for like the Google people
right in terms of how much data but
where you have to do it in the cloud
well CMS has done a little bit of stuff
in the cloud with AWS but never with
personal health information
so here I come with my security team
trying to convince them that we should
be the first to put 74 million Americans
data in the cloud for performance for
use and I didn't have any concerns about
security because I knew about all my
other federal peers DoD many others who
had gone ahead of us but it was still an
uphill battle we still have a lot of
course important high security
requirements and because it was the
first time at my agency there was a lot
of trepidation so that was fun we got
through that and now we actually have it
up and now it's considered a landmark
and others are moving to the cloud with
their data at CMS regardless of whether
it's PII or pH I and our infrastructure
itself supported with some of the
vendors I saw as I walk through their
data bricks and so forth and we're using
Amazon redshift part of that
infrastructure now we have other federal
agencies coming to check it out to say
how do you do that how do you produce it
because it's this constant influx of
very complex data from as I said 51
different paths that we did try to get
them to a single data dictionary which
is like matchmaking time 251 and we
brought them all in and every time we
ingest that data it has to go through
very complex business rules to make sure
that the data has some sense to it and
also flagging things that we may need to
look into so it's quite a big enterprise
but it's already producing so we've
already shared the data with our
oversight bodies like the Congressional

looking at it already for fraud and
abuse for those Medicare and Medicaid
participating providers having an
impossible day where they saw 40
patients on each program that kind of
silliness and we've given the data to a
technical experts paddle to really dig
in and understand States data quality
because to be clear what we've built
with AWS is an operational
data set it's not academic we're not
going to like this is a clinical trial
not dissing those things but this is an
operational data set we need to use it
as it comes in and it will never be
perfect I tell people that all the time
I know it's a downer but this data set
will never be perfect because it's real
and that's how healthcare data is people
submit claims and they argue with the
payer about that amount and it goes back
and forth and back and forth it's a
while before you get that final claim
and in Medicaid we can have retroactive
eligibility back 90 days so people start
date isn't exactly there application
date it can be messy state systems have
problems or go up and down the managed
care plans change
but if we have real transparency into
what is and is not there then we can
tell you what to look for so now you're
informed consumers with that data
so what AWS also allows us to do besides
running all those tools and edits so
that we can see the goods of bad and
ugly
it also lets us share the data in a more
creative way I mean this is as I said
massive amounts of data not like I can

on CMS gov there needs to be ways that
we can share it more creatively with our

most exciting is the peer to peer there
are other federal agencies who also use
AWS and also need this information that
would be a lot easier for me can we push
things into s3 and how people do
download there's a lot of options for us
so again it's all about performance and
use and I'm happy about the storage I
like the pay-as-you-go I used to have to
pay a lot of money for a database space
that I never actually used that's not
fun but so that does help it does
sometimes challenge you in predictive
budgeting but we're working on it but
really for us and back to that original
company for them it was a no-brainer
that was part of our solution and there

that we could integrate with all our
business intelligence tools they were
sold we got our security people sold and
we're working on the data-driven culture

ask those questions and understand the
quality of the data as well as an
ongoing operation
so as Venter said I am have the

program and leading our data and IT work
